Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CEDAR: High-Resolution Imaging of Instability Dynamics and Breakdown
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a 3-year collaborative investigation between The Aerospace Corporation and GATS Inc. to place a new airglow camera at the Andes Lidar Observatory (ALO) in Chile and use those data to study turbulent processes near the mesopause. Turbulent viscosity is a critical unknown parameter in numerical models of the 80 to 100 km altitude region. It is notoriously very difficult to measure. This project will provide a method of measuring this parameter in this important atmospheric region where turbulent viscosity may vary by 3 orders of magnitude. The results of this study will also contribute to a more general understanding of fluid dynamics accompanying flow instabilities.
Specifically, this project will utilize the Aerospace Corporation?s new high-resolution infrared camera (AIC2) that uses fast optics and a 2048 x 2048 IR detector to image the OH airglow at 30 m pixel size with a 2 s image cadence. The ALO site also includes a Na wind-temperature lidar and a meteor radar. Data from the AIC2 and the other ALO instruments will be used to investigate the breakdown into turbulence of Kelvin-Helmholtz instabilities (KHIs) and to measure the turbulent viscosity. This new technique will allow characterization of the turbulent viscosity for a variety of background conditions and over daily and seasonal timescales. The measurements will be combined with high-resolution direct numerical simulations to produce the most complete picture to date of KHI breakdown and its evolution into turbulence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Aerospace Corpoaration developed ANI2, a high spatial resolution imager that is capable of imaging the OH airglow layer at about 25 m pixel size near 90 km altitude the region where the airglow emits. The imager uses a 2K x 2K Teledyne H2RG detector, filtered to the H band, from about 1.5 to 1.7 microns, which is cooled by a Cobham cryocooler to about 140 K. The instrument has a 29.6 degree field of view. It operates from dawn to dusk during Moon down conditions and is located at the Andes Lidar Observatory on Cerro Pachon, Chile where some of the clearest nightsky conditions exist. This instrument obtained data from Feb 2016 to Oct 2018 and then was redployed in Jan 2020.  Prior to ANI2,  Aerrospace opearted ANI1 a somewhat lower rseolution imager from 2009 to 2016.  Acess to summary data are at http://www.ctio.noao.edu/ALO/. 

 

The main use of such imagers are to observe perturbations in the natural OH emission, which is typically not visible to the human eye but is to our sensor. These variations are typically caused by atmospheric gravity waves (AGWs) which are produced in the lower atmosphere by either thunderstorms or other weather, or flow over mountains in which case they  are called mountain waves. AGWs propogate up to the OH layer where they are so large they can break down forming structures like Kelvin-Helmoltz Instability (KHI)  billows  that  themselves can break down onto turbulence. Thus, our studies utilize the atmosphere as a natural laboratory for turbulence formation.

While the main goal was to obtain of images for future analysis the data were used for two scientific investigations. The first utilized the older ANI1 imager to study for the first time the detailed breakldown of a mountain wave into turbulent-like structures. The most suprising result was the appearence of vortex rings. These are horseshoe shaped structures that have been seen in the lower atmosphere and while they were predicted in the upper atmosphere they had not been previously positively idendified. Figure 2 of the Open Access paper below shows an example of a vortext ring.

The second investigation utilized the high spatial resolution of ANI2 to investigae a spectacular KHI breakdown event. This study is currently in review for ultimate publication in JGR atmospheres under the second  and third titles below. The first is the observations portion, still under review, while the second,  which has been accepted, is the modeling study led by our colleague Dr. David Fritts. The main consequence of this  investigation was that the region where the KHI billows join, referred to as a knot, is where there can be intense production of turbulence. Interestingly knots were first seen in the laboratory many years ago by Prof Steve Thorpe as described in a study referenced below. This combination of investigations is a nice example of the connection between laboratory studies, modeling, and atmospheric observations. It gives confidence that we are making progress in understanding  the formation of turbulence.
